required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Smartmesh Technology in Pelvic Floor Repair Procedures
clinical_study.official_title: Transvaginal Treatment of Anterior and Apical Genital Prolapses Using an Ultra Lightweight Mesh: Restorelle® Direct FixTM: a Retrospective Study on Feasibility and Morbidity.

lead_sponsor.agency: Groupe Hospitalier de la Rochelle Ré Aunis

clinical_study.source: Groupe Hospitalier de la Rochelle Ré Aunis

brief_summary.textblock: Pelvic organ prolapse repair involves conservative treatments and surgical treatments. Conservative treatments are for patients with moderate prolapse. Treatment of symptomatic prolapse remains essentially surgical. According to detailed medical history and a thorough physical exam, surgical techniques may be performed by high abdominal, low vaginal or mixed routes with or without the use of a reinforcing implant. Restorelle Direct Fix is indicated for transvaginal anterior and posterior surgical repair either as mechanical support or as reinforcement of pelvic floor defects. Advantages and disadvantages of vaginal prostheses are known but only limited data have been reported on the use of Restorelle® in the treatment of pelvic organ prolapse. This study is designed to collect data on the safety and efficacy of Restorelle® Direct Fix in pelvic organ prolapse repair.

detailed_description.textblock: Between January 2013 and December 2016, in the participating centers, all adult women who underwent surgery to repair pelvic organ prolapse (recurrent or not) through the vagina with the addition of anterior and/or posterior Restorelle Direct Fix prosthesis are eligible. Collected data are about the peri-operative period and the data available at the last consultation.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Patients With a Composite Outcome : Bladder Wound, Rectum Wound, Abnormal Bleeding

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Patients With Early Complications
secondary_outcome.description: Urinary retention, urinary tract infection, hematoma, ureteral complication, second surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Patients With Late Complications
secondary_outcome.description: self-catheterization, recurrent urinary tract infections, de novo urinary stress incontinence, chronic pain, vaginal prosthesis exposure, prolapse recurrence, secondary surgery, other

secondary_outcome.measure: Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) Exam Before Surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Pelvic organ prolapse quantification (POP-Q) Staging Criteria Prolapse is staged using POP-Q criteria that can range from good support (no organ descent) reported as a POP-Q stage 0 or I to a POP-Q score of IV (complete procidentia or vault eversion)

secondary_outcome.measure: Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) Exam After Surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Pelvic organ prolapse quantification (POP-Q) Staging Criteria Prolapse is staged using POP-Q criteria that can range from good support (no organ descent) reported as a POP-Q stage 0 or I to a POP-Q score of IV (complete procidentia or vault eversion)

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Patients With Preoperative Urinary Signs
secondary_outcome.description: urinary stress incontinence, overactive bladder, dysuria, masked urinary incontinence

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Patients With Postoperative Urinary Signs
secondary_outcome.description: urinary stress incontinence, overactive bladder, dysuria, masked urinary incontinence

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Patients With Preoperative Digestive Signs
Number of Patients With Postoperative Digestive Signs
Number of Patients With Preoperative Active Sexuality
Number of Patients With Preoperative Dyspareunia
Number of Patients With Postoperative Active Sexuality
Number of Patients With Postoperative Dyspareunia
Preoperative Score at Numeric Pain Rating Scale
secondary_outcome.description: The numeric pain rating scale ranges from 0 (no pain) to 10 (worst pain imaginable)

secondary_outcome.measure: Postoperative Score at Numeric Pain Rating Scale
secondary_outcome.description: The numeric pain rating scale ranges from 0 (no pain) to 10 (worst pain imaginable)

intervention.description: Surgery to repair pelvic organ prolapse through the vagina using stitches with the addition of surgical mesh.

study_pop.textblock: Adult women who underwent surgery to repair pelvic organ prolapse (recurrent or not) through the vagina with the addition of anterior and/or posterior Restorelle Direct Fix prosthesis

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Over 18
- woman who underwent surgery to repair pelvic organ prolapse (recurrent or not) through the vagina with the addition of anterior and/or posterior Restorelle Direct Fix prosthesis
- informed and not opposed to the use of her data
Exclusion Criteria:
- Opposed to the use of her data

Clinique St Michel et St Anne

link.description: Association Française de Normalisation (AFNOR). Norme Française (NF) S 94-801 implants de renfort mis en place par voie vaginale pour cure d'incontinence urinaire d'effort et/ou de prolapsus des organes pelviens. Essais pré-cliniques et essais cliniques

reference.citation: Le Normand L, Cosson M, Cour F, Deffieux X, Donon L, Ferry P, Fatton B, Hermieu JF, Marret H, Meurette G, Cortesse A, Wagner L, Fritel X. [Clinical practice guidelines: Summary of recommendations for first surgical treatment of female pelvic organ prolapse by 5 French academic societies: AFU, CNGOF, SIFUD-PP, SNFCP, and SCGP]. Prog Urol. 2016 Jul;26 Suppl 1:S1-7. doi: 10.1016/S1166-7087(16)30424-9. Review. French.
Khunda A, Vashisht A, Cutner A. New procedures for uterine prolapse. Best Pract Res Clin Obstet Gynaecol. 2013 Jun;27(3):363-79. doi: 10.1016/j.bpobgyn.2012.12.004. Epub 2013 Jan 5. Review.
Olsen AL, Smith VJ, Bergstrom JO, Colling JC, Clark AL. Epidemiology of surgically managed pelvic organ prolapse and urinary incontinence. Obstet Gynecol. 1997 Apr;89(4):501-6.

Nygaard I, Barber MD, Burgio KL, Kenton K, Meikle S, Schaffer J, Spino C, Whitehead WE, Wu J, Brody DJ; Pelvic Floor Disorders Network. Prevalence of symptomatic pelvic floor disorders in US women. JAMA. 2008 Sep 17;300(11):1311-6. doi: 10.1001/jama.300.11.1311.
Persu C, Chapple CR, Cauni V, Gutue S, Geavlete P. Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification System (POP-Q) - a new era in pelvic prolapse staging. J Med Life. 2011 Jan-Mar;4(1):75-81. Epub 2011 Feb 25.
Lousquy R, Costa P, Delmas V, Haab F. [Update on the epidemiology of genital prolapse]. Prog Urol. 2009 Dec;19(13):907-15. doi: 10.1016/j.purol.2009.09.011. Epub 2009 Nov 4. Review. French.

Maher C, Feiner B, Baessler K, Christmann-Schmid C, Haya N, Marjoribanks J. Transvaginal mesh or grafts compared with native tissue repair for vaginal prolapse. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2016 Feb 9;2:CD012079. doi: 10.1002/14651858.CD012079. Review.

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Between January 2013 and December 2016, in 10 secondary and tertiary French care centres
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Patients were excluded if they did not attend their follow up visit within 30 days of surgery.

reported_events.time_frame: The median follow-up was 3 months ranging from 1 to 36 months

group.title: Pelvic Organ Prolapse Repair
group.description: Adult women who had vaginal repair of pelvic organ prolapse (recurrent or not) planned with anterior Restorelle® Direct FixTM mesh (with or without posterior mesh)

event.description: postoperative complication in the month following the surgery
Of the 272 patients included, 220 were reviewed at more than one month postoperatively. The description of adverse events is therefore only available for these patients.

event.sub_title: Adverse local tissue reaction around prosthesis
event.description: Of the 272 patients included, 220 were reviewed at more than one month postoperatively. The description of adverse events is therefore only available for these patients.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
